courses.course_name: History of the Greek and Latin Languages
courses.course_description: (same as LINGST 4130; cross-leveled with CLASS 7100, LINGST 7130). Evolution of classical languages and their relationship to each other.
Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.  Departmental consent for repetition.

courses.course_name: Introduction to Text Criticism and Paleography
courses.course_description: (cross-leveled with CLASS 7300). Latin and/or Greek textual criticism and paleography, using manuscript facsimiles at the University library.
(cross-leveled with CLASS 7400). Reading and interpretation of pastoral poetry and prose in Greek and Latin; emphasis on Theocritus, Virgil, and Longus.

courses.course_name: Advanced Study in the Teaching of the Classics

courses.course_description: Readings in authors and texts not covered in other courses.
Culminating course in the study of Greek and Roman literature and Classical culture.  Required for Greek, Latin, and Classical Languages majors in first term of senior year.

Culminating course in the study of Greek and Roman literature and Classical culture.  Required for Greek, Latin, and Classical Languages majors in first term of senior year.  Recommended for double-majors.
Limited to Honors undergraduates. To be taken in senior year. Integrated exploration of classical civilization. May repeat to 6 hours maximum.

courses.course_name: Introduction to Graduate Study in Classics
courses.course_description: Required of all first-year graduate students.

courses.course_name: History of the Greek and Latin Languages
courses.course_description: (same as LINGST 7130; cross-levelled with CLASS 4100, LINGST 4130). Evolution of classical languages and their relationship to each other.
Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. Departmental consent for repetition.

courses.course_name: Introduction to Text Criticism and Paleography
courses.course_description: (cross-leveled with CLASS 4300). Latin and/or Greek textual criticism and paleography, using manuscript facsimiles at the University library.
courses.prerequisites: 2 years of Classical Languages or equivalent

courses.course_description: (cross-leveled with CLASS 4400). Reading and interpretation of pastoral poetry and prose in Greek and Latin; emphasis on Theocritus, Virgil, and Longus.
courses.prerequisites: 2 years each of Greek and Latin

courses.course_name: Advanced Study in the Teaching of the Classics
courses.prerequisites: classroom teaching experience or chairman's consent

courses.course_description: Readings in authors and texts not covered in other courses.
courses.prerequisites: graduate standing and classics/classical humanities; departmental consent; Greek--two years classical Greek or equivalent; Latin--two years Classical Latin or equivalent

courses.course_description: For graduate students to undertake special projects for graduate credit under the supervision of faculty.

courses.course_name: Masters Research and Thesis in Classics
courses.course_description: For graduate students studying for the MA and working on a thesis to receive credit for work directly related to the thesis.  Graded S/U only.
(same as AR_H_A 8440). Descriptive and historical analysis of selected city or site. Subject varies.
Individual research in preparation for writing thesis and/or dissertation. Graded on a S/U basis only.
Intensive study of classical mythology in origin, development, meaning and influence.
Seminar in the Hellenistic Age

courses.course_name: Seminar in Ancient Rhetoric and Oratory
courses.course_description: Seminar in Ancient Rhetoric and Oratory
Principles and theories of ancient Greek and Latin literary criticism, as developed in significant works on the subject.
Critical and comparative study of Greek and Latin didactic poetry with emphasis on major authors from Hesiod through the Augustan Age.
Seminar in Greco-Roman Religion

courses.course_name: Seminar in Greco-Roman Satire and Social Criticism
courses.course_description: Seminar in Greco-Roman Satire and Social Criticism
